title: about
text:
I’m a compiler engineer at NVIDIA, working on compilation of large language models to domain-specific architectures for inference acceleration.
I received my PhD in Computer Science from Aarhus University, Denmark, where I worked on modular specification and formal verification of distributed systems using separation logic and the Roc proof assistant.
My interests are in the areas of programming languages, compilers, and formal verification.

title: Solutions to Simmons’ Intro to Category Theory (Chapter 1)
text:
To verify that \(\textbf{Pno}\) is a category we need to check that composition of arrows is well-defined and that the identity arrow behaves as expected.
Let \((A, \alpha, a) \xrightarrow{f} (B, \beta, b)\) and \((B, \beta, b) \xrightarrow{g} (C, \gamma, c)\).
Then we have:

\((g \circ f)(a) = g(f(a)) = c\)
The second coherence condition follows from \[\begin{align*}
  (g \circ f) \circ \alpha &= g \circ (f \circ \alpha) \\
  &= g \circ (\beta \circ f) \\
  &= (g \circ \beta) \circ f \\
  &= (\gamma \circ g) \circ f \\
  &= \gamma \circ (g \circ f)
  \end{align*}\]

title: Solutions to Simmons’ Intro to Category Theory (Chapter 1)
text:
To verify that \(\textbf{Pno}\) is a category we need to check that composition of arrows is well-defined and that the identity arrow behaves as expected.
Let \((A, \alpha, a) \xrightarrow{f} (B, \beta, b)\) and \((B, \beta, b) \xrightarrow{g} (C, \gamma, c)\).
Then we have:

\((g \circ f)(a) = g(f(a)) = c\)
The second coherence condition follows from \[\begin{align*}
  (g \circ f) \circ \alpha &= g \circ (f \circ \alpha) \\
  &= g \circ (\beta \circ f) \\
  &= (g \circ \beta) \circ f \\
  &= (\gamma \circ g) \circ f \\
  &= \gamma \circ (g \circ f)
  \end{align*}\]

title: An experiment in writing things down
text: I’ve long wanted to start a blog, mainly to write down things that I learn (mostly for myself but possibly others as well).
